topic.body:
When I enable Always, it can't connect to peers, can't get new content, can't publish/post, etc,...

## How to identify IP
When set to Available, your IP shows up on the first line next to rev4172

http://127.0.0.1:43110/Stats

Only when you are using Tor Always is only correctly different from output of command line:

```curl ifconfig.me```

topic.title: Korean ZT Post - What is zeronet?
topic.body:
I was curious what other countries were saying about ZN, so translated this post below.  It is interesting that they are using mesh networks to connect.  

English translation via goggles...

## [What is a zeronet? (Revised 2018-11-18)](http://127.0.0.1:43110/16J4mEgR5aqerfzGy2WctNV3onPQUgF2E5/?Topic:1521099018_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm/+2018+11+18)

Zeronet is a new network that will replace the functionality of the existing Internet.

In other words, people using zeronet can essentially enjoy the same or similar service as the existing internet within zeronet without paying for a subscription to an existing Internet provider or connecting to the Internet using public Wi-Fi. .

Of course, you can only get new information by connecting to someone else's computer, whether by router or something. (An easy way is to connect to a zeronet peer over the Internet over an existing Internet line.)

Logically, if you assume that multiple people are rotating around on a single computer without having to connect to anything, you can enjoy the same benefits as the traditional Internet.

To make it easier,
The war broke out. Kori Nuclear Power Plant exploded and destroyed all electrical facilities, Internet communication network and Daum Net and Naver headquarters data center. By the way, there's a person in a small town who has a router, runs a router with a photovoltaic generator, and distributes the router connection number to people.
Each person charges their laptop or smartphone with a manual generator to access the router's Wi-Fi.
Of course, because Internet facility was cut off, we cannot connect to Daum net or Naver.
However, if each person has a zeronet installed on the PC or smart phone, anyone can hit http://127.0.0.1:43110/ in the browser address bar to talk to the zeronet and talk about the information as if they are connected to the next net or Naver. To share.

(Download the zeronet installation file):

    Windows version
    Apple macOS
    Linux Debian ARM
    Linux 64-bit x86
    Linux 32-bit x86

When you go out of the router's support range and go home and your family's computers and smartphones are all connected, all of the other router's information is automatically updated on your device. You can also pick up a computer with stories, opinions, and information you shared with each other and go back to the router in the town so everyone can read the information and attach your own opinions.

(Of course, you can also send and receive secret messages between individuals using zero mail.)

> [ayylmaolol](#comment_5_1E5GcuKhRw6sujdX3XKosJ54HFJ4pMtr14): Are you on Windows or on Linux?On windows it ships with an tor instance and it should work out of the box.On Linux you have to setup your own Tor or use the Tor Browser instance by settingtor_controller = 127.0.0.1:9151tor_proxy = 127.0.0.1:9150in zeronet.conf

I'm on Linux running Tor as an independently installed service (via package manager) as well as using the Tor browser.  I know ZN is talking to the service because if the service isn't running, ZN hows an error in it's start logs.  ZN shows that it is available when it is running.  So, it's using ports 9151/9150, the default ports, even w/o those entries in zeronet.conf.

One thing I've observed, is if I put 

tor_controller = 127.0.0.1:9151
tor_proxy = 127.0.0.1:9150

in zeronet.conf

it shows as Available w/o tor service running.  but, without those lines, it disables Tor on ZN startup, unless I have the service running.  

To put it different, if you don't have a Tor service running OR do not includes those lines, you'll see this at ZN startup:

TorManager Disabling Tor, because error while accessing Tor proxy at port 127.0.0.1:9050: No connection 

This does nothing to address original question.  Still can't publish, dl new content, or have an IP not mine in /Stats when Tor Always.

The post from nickwa helped me get a lot more successful trackers (26/49 from 3/12):

1562000931_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body:
Take a look at how Bisq has a unique decentralized governance model.  They created the DAO token where all owners of that own Bisq by being able to vote for new features. It is then used to pay contributors.  So, if someone translates into another language, they can submit a request to be paid for it.  If voted, they get DAO as payment.  

In the ideal state, everyone would own ZN, and anyone can contribute to it, and be rewarded for it.  I noticed that nofish already let's people vote for features with BTC.  That concept could continue under this model, except they'd use a ZN token.    

https://bisq.network/dao/

Regarding GITHUB AND DISTRIBUTION (updates) it makes sense to mirror it at github and within ZN (Git Center), as both have pros and cons, github being more accessible today, and ZN being decentralized and resilient.  If a user can choose where to update it from, that would be a plus, too.  

If they are mirrored, I like the idea of changes originating inside ZN, then replicating to github, because this gives a contributor the option of not engaging in github.  I'm not sure how you handle that via github user credits, though.

Regarding GOVERNANCE over the core code, architecture, direction, etc,...  

There are other compelling reasons to pursue an improved model here:

- Increasing incentive to contribute.
- Increasing user commitment and base through increased stakeholder participation (e.g, voting, ownership).  The "user" here is a broad range of contributors to the value of the ecosystem, including, but not limited to
  1. site creators - creating consumable services and content that draws in consumers
  2. consumers - the end-users give site creators incentive to build, increase replication of content, promote through word-of-mouth, clearnet, and other means.  

If core developers are incentivized, it can open the doors to broader possibilities for where ZN can be in 1 to 5 years, and broaden the range of potential site creators and consumers.  

Due to these synergies, it is in all stakeholders' interest, including nofish, to remove the friction for new contributors to join, and incentivizing them with rewards.  This is why we can aspire to build a new decentralized governance model for core and other contributors.

There are really two separate issues here:
- [bootstrapping zites](/1NtQvrYd8rJzQYP3j1snmi28mPn8wSXX4X/?Page:zeronet-default-apps) (ZeroHello)
- ZeroNet core

This is a chicken and egg.  But, we should talk about the bootstrapping zites separately, because until we have a better more decentralized ZeroHello, changing ownership isn't likely to help.  

I can't speak for 0fish, but based on what he's created so far, I suspect if we created a better ZeroHello, he'd be more than happy to use it in bootstrapping the home page.

1565420698_1GFU4qAMTFnQJ7W7r98Zj2xJWq1ev.body:
> [capitanjack](#comment_7_1DNJ1b7d7bqeZHigy35ZKBwwe8PBv8o7Gk): It is implemented on some cloud drives. They scan users folder for files hashs and that way can found out if someone used to have cp etc. So yea there also must be big databases with hash list done of those images.

That appending of new hashes today begins with a process of "trusted" humans identifying the images then submitting it through a trusted and controlled process.  That becomes very difficult to distribute in a p2p world because w/o that central trust and control, you open the door to DOS attacks.  e.g., a bad actor could scan all images of a target site and submit the hashes even though none may belong in the category.  

It certainly does make sense to use an existing database that is reputable and trustable and use it.  But, the longer term risk there is introducing a model for censorship that can potentially become broader than the category you were interested in blocking (e.g., blocking political expression).

Is there documentation on how to configure ZN for an offline mesh?  The issue is bootstrapping, discovery and trackers.  If you read the Japanese one, they are not very happy about the discovery process of ZN.  

In a pure offline mesh, you may need some sort of gossip/DHT for peers to find each other on bootup.    

By offline mesh, it means peers of the mesh (not ZN yet) find each other and connect.  There is no DHCP or typical router functions.  You do not need a router.  Routers in that typically act as "boosters", as they often have higher power transmissions than a cell phone.  But, otherwise, they are primarily acting as peers themselves.  

So Bob and Alice can connect their cell phones or computers w/o a router via Wifi Direct.  John and Sally may connect, but be too far for Bob and Alice.  Throw a "router" in the middle, and now the 4 of them can connect to each other because the distance is gapped.

But, this still doesn't explain how mesh networks get built with 1000 devices across 100 sq miles, because you'll have many tiny subnets in there.  No way to have one master.  

Some of these mesh networks use bluetooth, but I'm discounting that cuz the distance sucks.  But, if you have power limitations (limited solar), you may have a combo of BLE and Wifi in your mesh.

1565652073_1KUSKrffaR1sfLwxZUXUPshLpKhh5.body:
1> PUBLISHING.  When you publish your new site, you are the only seeder.  As people come to your site, they become seeder, but may not be seeders forever.  I'm not sure what garbage collection is done.  But if you are the only seeder, then it is effectively offline when you shut your computer down.  But, if you get other seeders first, and there is always at least 1 seeder online all night, then it will be available to the world all night while your computer is down.  

It is possible to have 10 seeders, then they die off, and you become the only seeder again.  In which case, you'll need to get people to come to your site again.  Note that you can access it from multiple computers or devices to seed multiple times.  

2.0> ZITES.  User sites are static web sites of primarily HTML/Javascript/CSS.  There is no server side language like PHP.  ZeroNet itself happens to run on PHP.  But, the user created sites/content in ZN is not.  You have a file system based database available to you, which is part of your site.  But, when a user accesses a ZITE, all the files they are accessing are local on their file system after being downloaded, including any data.  Also, all users of all ZITES can view the source code, because it is plain text HTML, etc,...
2.1> ZITES ownership.  Your private key created when you created your site is not published, and thus that gives you the ability to do things such as moderate content as well as publish.  If you lose this, you lose the ability to publish updates to your site or any other feature you built in such as controlling who can moderate.   

3> SIZE LIMITS. There are default limits to site sizes that viewers can control and volunteer to increase as needed when prompted, file size limits, and user content limits I believe the site owner can set to protect the site from things like spam that would apply to each individual user of your site.  .

I'm no expert, but this is my understanding so far.  So, a more seasoned expert can confirm or clarify.

This is as assumption, not the truth.  If merging of pull requests is decentralized, then peer review and acceptance of new code is decentralized to the extent the community stakeholders can vote.  Funding new features can also be decentralized, increasing the incentive for anyone able and willing to become a developer while giving the community a bigger say in priorities.      

Half of what you're saying are points I'd make for having a vision and road map for decentralizing development.  For example:

Under the current centralized model, we have very little incentive to increase peer review of design, because no one has a vote at the end of the day.  The more eyes we have reviewing features and code before being merged, the better our security model will be.  Increasing ownership is one way to increase participation in development.

1566439997_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUt.body:
I love IPFS, especially with FUSE.  It's a learning curve due to its abstractions, but pretty cool and worth the curve.  

The two biggest issues for combining with ZeroNet are performance and privacy.  

Performance can be improved. We'll see how that develops.  I don't understand its bottlenecks well.  

Do you have a privacy solution?  I am not aware of a way to make it work on Tor.  

It's a paradigm shift, because your IP is much like your number.  You probably don't want the whole world to know it, especially if it is static.  Unfortunately, the potential for harm is far greater if someone has your IP than your phone number.  We've taken it for granted that using third party sites like Google and Twitter hides our IP from our peers.  If you have time, see if you can get it running in Whonix, which forces everything on the VM through Tor.  Their wiki has instructions for services that do work in it, including ZeroNet, to help you understand how to open ports.    

That said, IPFS has a lot of promising use cases on its own.  And, perhaps one day, it can fill a niche within ZeroNet, or there can be bridging or mirroring. .

> [blurhy](#comment_315_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUtTpcK): IPZN will be a superset, because it's designed for any infrastructure.

How is reputation playing a role?  

In general, I only trust **trustless** networks.  There may be times when reputation solves a unique problem without doing harm, though, so I don't automatically rule it out, but do ask, how can it do harm.  Slashdot uses it successfully for content moderation, but all comments are visible to anyone who wants to see them.  P2P could use it to determine if someone is human.  

I'm considering very open reputation calculations to determine if someone is human for voting purposes to counter sybil attacks where someone uses bots to game the system.  But, once a person meets the "isHuman" threshold, I'd like to stop there.
